Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 5 - usually just reading, more depending on assignment due dates (during those weeks about 10)
5-6 hours when an assignment was due

It was very helpful to have clinicians' views on the healthcare epidemiology issues especially from people who were able to experience things first-hand, but at the same time I thought that made it difficult to have discussions among people who did not have first hand experiences.

The course was ok.  I felt as though the final exam and some homework assignments were outside the scope of the class.  Some lectures seemed irrelevent.  If I am coming to an 8am class every week, I think it is reasonable to have the material needed for assignments to be presented in class rather than needing to rely heavily on readings.  
I also felt that the nurses and doctors in the class had more respect from the professors than the MPH students.  The professors would often direct questions to the nurses and doctors when many of the MPH students had strong background on that topic and could answer the question.  It made me feel discouraged from volunteering when questions were not directed towards me.

I learned so much - real-world components were definitely a strength, weaknesses were that the course overall used a lot of jargon that those who have not spent time in hospitals might not understand.

Guest lecturer format made it a little bit disjointed. Would have been nice to have some case study homework to practice. Really truly spent an hour and a half talking about how to wash hands. Sometimes the vibe seemed a little condescending towards the non-clinical people
2 hour lectures can be a bit dry

Good overview of issues in healthcare epidemiology.  Many of the guest speakers were very good and engaging.  As this was a smaller class, it would have been nice to have more in-class interaction with the other students through scenarios, etc.  It was nice having doctors and infection preventionists in the class.  I wish we could have heard their perspective more often.

Some of the readings for the homework assignments were not always relevant to the essay question.

I really enjoyed this course.  Its material was exactly what I expected when signing up for the course; it was a great introduction to different areas of healthcare epidemiology.  The hospital tour was one of my favorite parts of the class, and I think that this experience was very important for MPH students with minimal clinical exposure.

It was nice to have experts present the topics in which they specialize. Dr. Dembry and Dr. Banach always provided very useful feedback. I liked the short assignments we did and the group project. The hospital tour is also a great aspect of the class.
Too lecture based, seemed like unnecessary information
Wonderful course. I feel that it should be mandatory for all YSPH students. I greatly enjoyed class discussions and hearing the numerous guest lecturers that came to class.
na
Well-spoken, knowledgeable, and patient with questions

I also felt that the nurses and doctors in the class had more respect from the professors than the MPH students.  The professors would often direct questions to the nurses and doctors when many of the MPH students had strong background on that topic and could answer the question.  It made me feel discouraged from volunteering when questions were not directed towards me.
Incredibly open, always happy to explain things - lots of great experience and I'm glad to have taken a class with Dr. Banach!
Seemed more open minded and accessible
Good!
Well spoken and smart.  Could have been a little more enthusiastic when teaching.
Dr. Banach was engaging and passionate about this material.  He presented clearly, and was helpful to answer any questions we had.
Very straightforward
Excellent Professor. Would not change anything.
na
Well-spoken, knowledgeable, and patient with questions

I also felt that the nurses and doctors in the class had more respect from the professors than the MPH students.  The professors would often direct questions to the nurses and doctors when many of the MPH students had strong background on that topic and could answer the question.  It made me feel discouraged from volunteering when questions were not directed towards me.

So much experience and always willing to share how things happen in reality versus how they're written in a textbook. Appreciate the format and professionalism of the class as well. I also loved the helpful feedback - so essential to learning!
Good!
Very knowledgeable, provided good examples from her career.  Also approachable.
I enjoyed having Dr. Dembry as an instructor.  She has a lot of experience to draw from, and it was always interesting to hear about a real situation where the things we learned could be applied.
Amazing professor
Excellent Professor. Would not change anything.
na

In-depth look at healthcare epidemiology especially through both clinician and epidemiologist perspectives. Yes I would recommend this to a student since I found it an interesting and focused topic to learn about.
This course was just ok.  An 8am class should be more engaging.  Some assignments were graded harshly, and material needed for assignments is not always covered in class.
If you want to learn about how Epidemiology is applied in hospital settings, this course is for you!

While it sucks that this class is at 8am, it's relatively low-workload and only requires as much effort as you want to give it. Class is a mix of public health and clinical students, including a bunch of nurses who are already infection preventionists, which was made very obvious all the time. If you're dedicated, it's an interesting overview of how to apply epi to infection prevention, but it felt disjointed (lots of guest lecturers) with no common thread and no real practice homeworks.
A good course for those looking to understand infection control in a hospital/ healthcare setting. A lot of clinicians in the class, but don't need a clinical background to understand the material.
Good overview course of important issues in infection prevention in the healthcare setting.  I would recommend it if you are very interested in this topic.

I would recommend this course to another student.  Hospital exposures are one of the most important sources of infectious disease burden in the United States, and as students of public health here, I think it is important for all of us to have some hospital epidemiology knowledge.
If you are interested in the subject, you should take this course
na
